15.title: Testing or Refuting Converse/Inverse of a Conditional Statement
15.description: This function involves explicitly examining whether the converse (or sometimes the inverse) of a given conditional statement is valid—i.e., whether "If A → B" allows us to infer "If B, then A" or "If not B, then not A." Sentences in this category typically articulate that the original implication does NOT guarantee its converse, often using examples or counterexamples to show that the reverse direction is not logically justified. This reasoning step usually appears after the initial statement of a conditional and serves to clarify the limits of what can be inferred, but does not include general explanations of conditionals, nor does it include affirming the original direction of the implication.
examples: So, just because eating ice cream makes Tom happy doesn't automatically mean that whenever Tom is happy, he must have eaten ice cream
So, just because Jane passed the exam (P), we can't conclude she studied hard (S), because maybe there are other reasons why she passed
So, in this case, since all experts have degrees, but not all degree holders are experts, Sarah having a degree doesn't automatically make her an expert
So, just because Wind causes Rustling doesn't mean Rustling can only happen if Wind is present
So just because schools closed today (Q), it doesn't necessarily mean it snowed (P)
Just because all geniuses are creative doesn't mean that all creative people are geniuses
So, if all experts have degrees, that means Expert → Degree
So, in logic terms, if A implies B, then knowing B doesn't necessarily mean A is true unless we have more information
So, just because Jane passed the exam, does that mean she studied hard
In logic, knowing that G is true doesn't necessarily mean F is true unless F is the only way G can happen
just because someone has a degree doesn't mean they're an expert
But the question is the converse: if Tina works hard, does she have to be successful
That is, if Tom is happy now, does that mean he must have eaten ice cream
The question is: If all students who study hard pass the exam, and Jane passed the exam, can we conclude that she studied hard
So, the key here is that just because all professional basketball players are tall doesn't mean that all tall people are professional basketball players

categories: Pattern Identification and Explicit Enumeration

These sentences serve the function of explicitly listing, enumerating, or breaking down the elements of a sequence, set, or pattern in order to identify regularities or rules governing the data. Included are statements that systematically lay out the given items (numbers, letters, shapes, etc.), calculate differences or ratios, or otherwise make the structure of the data explicit for subsequent analysis. Not included are sentences that merely state the final pattern, draw conclusions, or perform calculations without first enumerating or analyzing the raw elements. These sentences typically appear early in the reasoning process, immediately after the problem is introduced and before any conclusions or predictions are made.
Expanding the Scope of Consideration

These sentences serve the cognitive function of deliberately broadening the reasoning process by introducing additional relevant factors, perspectives, or dimensions that have not yet been addressed. This includes bringing in new variables, implications, examples, or domains (e.g., economic, ethical, historical) for further analysis, often signaled by phrases like "I should also think about..." or "I'm also considering...". This category does NOT include initial identification of the main problem, deep analysis of a single factor, or summarizing conclusions; rather, these sentences typically appear after some initial reasoning, as the thinker seeks to ensure a comprehensive and multi-faceted exploration of the issue.
Problem Framing and Task Articulation

These sentences serve to explicitly state the central question, problem, or causal scenario that the reasoning process will address. They include the identification of a phenomenon, system, or hypothetical change and articulate the need to "figure out," "understand," or "analyze" its mechanisms, effects, or consequences. This function does NOT include the exploration of possible solutions, hypothesis generation, evidence evaluation, or step-by-step reasoning; rather, it is limited to the initial articulation of the reasoning target. These sentences almost always appear at or near the very beginning of a reasoning trace, setting the stage for subsequent analysis.
Enumeration of Total Possibilities Using Combinatorial Formulas

This function involves explicitly calculating or stating the total number of possible outcomes in a scenario by applying combinatorial formulas (such as combinations, permutations, or exponentiation for independent choices). Included are sentences that identify, set up, or compute the total count of arrangements, selections, or outcomes—often referencing formulas like C(n, k), P(n, k), n!, or expressions like 6^5. Not included are sentences that count favorable outcomes, describe problem constraints, or interpret the meaning of the result. These sentences typically appear early in probability or counting problems, immediately after the problem setup and before calculating probabilities or favorable cases.
Hypothesis Generation for Underlying Mechanisms

These sentences serve to propose possible explanations or mechanisms underlying observed phenomena or facts, often using tentative language ("maybe," "I think," "it has to do with," "perhaps," "or maybe"). This function includes the generation of causal or structural hypotheses about how or why something works, typically drawing on prior knowledge or analogies, but does NOT include definitive statements, direct recall of facts, or the evaluation/selection of hypotheses. These sentences usually appear in the exploratory or sense-making phase of reasoning, often after the problem is introduced but before a final answer or conclusion is reached.
Retrieval and Articulation of Background Knowledge

These sentences serve to recall, state, or paraphrase relevant factual information, definitions, or general properties from memory or prior knowledge, often as a foundation for further reasoning. Included are statements that explicitly present known facts, concepts, or examples (e.g., "I remember that artists use palettes to mix colors," "A cube has six faces, all squares, and all edges are equal in length"). Not included are sentences that interpret, analyze, hypothesize, or draw conclusions from this knowledge, nor those that merely express uncertainty or metacognitive reflection. These sentences typically appear early or mid-way in reasoning, immediately before or during the process of applying knowledge to the problem at hand.
Initiation of Deliberate, Stepwise Analytical Reasoning

These sentences explicitly signal the transition into a focused, methodical, and often step-by-step reasoning process. They serve to orient the model (and reader) toward breaking down a problem into manageable parts, often after an initial statement of the problem or when encountering complexity or uncertainty. INCLUDED are metacognitive prompts that announce the intent to analyze, decompose, or reconsider the problem systematically (e.g., "Let me think about this step by step," "Let me try to figure this out step by step," "Let me try to break this down"). NOT INCLUDED are actual analytical steps, conclusions, or mere restatements of the problem; these sentences do not perform reasoning themselves but rather initiate or re-initiate the analytical process. They typically appear at the beginning of the reasoning sequence or at key junctures where a new line of analysis is about to begin.
Generating Conditional Predictions and Inferences Based on Hypothetical Manipulations

These sentences perform the cognitive function of predicting or inferring the outcome of a hypothetical action or manipulation (e.g., "if I slice...", "if I rotate...", "if the light is coming from...") applied to a mathematical or physical object. Included are statements that explicitly describe what would result from a specific operation or condition, often using conditional or subjunctive language ("if...then...", "should be...", "would be..."). Not included are general definitions, explanations of concepts, or statements summarizing conclusions without reference to a hypothetical manipulation. These sentences typically appear in the middle of reasoning traces, as the thinker explores possible outcomes to test or build toward a solution.
Generating Alternative Hypothesis Candidates

These sentences serve the function of proposing possible explanations, interpretations, or candidate answers in response to a problem or question, often in a speculative or brainstorming mode. Included are statements that introduce new, distinct possibilities (e.g., "Maybe it's a metaphor," "Alternatively, maybe it's a keyhole," "Wait, maybe it's about the function"), typically using hedging language ("maybe," "perhaps," "alternatively," "another thought"). NOT INCLUDED are sentences that evaluate, justify, or select among these candidates, nor those that elaborate on a single hypothesis in depth. These sentences usually appear in the exploratory, generative phase of reasoning, often clustered after initial problem comprehension and before narrowing down or evaluating options.
Initial Problem Framing and Knowledge Activation

These sentences serve to initiate the reasoning process by explicitly framing the problem, recalling relevant prior knowledge, or identifying foundational concepts needed for further reasoning. INCLUDED are statements that mark the start of reasoning, such as recalling definitions, visualizing objects, or clarifying what needs to be understood before proceeding. NOT INCLUDED are sentences that analyze, synthesize, or evaluate information after the initial setup, or those that draw conclusions. These sentences almost always appear at or near the very beginning of a reasoning trace, setting the stage for subsequent cognitive operations.
Stepwise Explicit Calculation Execution

This function involves the explicit, step-by-step computation of arithmetic or algebraic operations, often breaking down complex calculations into smaller, manageable parts and showing intermediate results. Included are sentences that perform and narrate each sub-step of a calculation (e.g., multiplying, adding, dividing, simplifying fractions), often using phrases like "let me compute," "so," or "then," and presenting partial results. NOT INCLUDED are sentences that merely state the final answer, set up the problem, explain the reasoning behind the calculation, or interpret the result; only the explicit execution of calculation steps belongs here. These sentences typically appear in the middle of reasoning traces, directly after a problem is set up and before the final answer or interpretation is given.
Projecting Consequences and Secondary Effects

These sentences serve the cognitive function of forecasting possible outcomes, side effects, or ripple effects that may result from a proposed change, event, or intervention. Included in this category are statements that explicitly speculate about downstream impacts—both positive and negative—on systems, industries, societies, or the environment, often using modal verbs ("could," "might," "may") and conditional structures. NOT INCLUDED are direct explanations of mechanisms, definitions, or statements of fact; these sentences do not describe how something works, but rather what might happen as a result. They typically appear after an initial explanation or proposal, expanding the reasoning to consider broader or less direct implications.
Expression of Uncertainty or Doubt About a Prior Hypothesis or Step

These sentences explicitly signal the reasoner's uncertainty, doubt, or lack of confidence regarding the correctness, relevance, or sufficiency of a preceding idea, hypothesis, or reasoning step. Included are statements that hedge or qualify a just-made assertion (e.g., "But I'm not sure if that's the intended answer," "But I'm not entirely sure"), or that question the applicability, accuracy, or completeness of a prior thought. NOT INCLUDED are general expressions of confusion ("I don't understand"), requests for information, or uncertainty about facts not directly tied to a just-stated reasoning step. These sentences typically appear immediately after the reasoner proposes or considers a possible answer, explanation, or line of reasoning, serving as a metacognitive check before proceeding.
Analogical Structure Mapping and Target Identification

This function involves explicitly mapping the structure of an analogy or proportional relationship (e.g., "A is to B as C is to D") and reasoning through what the missing element (D) should be, based on the relationships among the other elements. Sentences in this category articulate the analogy, restate or clarify the relational structure, and propose or narrow down possible candidates for the missing term by aligning roles or functions across the analogy. INCLUDED: Sentences that set up, restate, or analyze the analogy’s structure and directly reason about what the missing element should be. NOT INCLUDED: Sentences that merely define terms, provide background knowledge, or state the final answer without explicit analogical mapping. These sentences typically appear after the problem is introduced and before the final answer is selected, serving as the core step in analogical reasoning.
Testing the Converse or Inverse of a Conditional Statement

This function involves explicitly examining whether the converse (or sometimes the inverse) of a given conditional statement holds true. Sentences in this category restate the original conditional (e.g., "If A, then B") and then question or analyze whether the reverse ("If B, then A") or the negation ("If not B, then not A") is valid, often using examples or logical notation. Included are statements that clarify the directionality of implication, test sufficiency vs. necessity, or highlight that the original conditional does not guarantee its converse; NOT included are sentences that merely restate the original conditional, provide definitions, or draw direct conclusions without testing the reverse relationship. These sentences typically appear after the initial statement of the problem and during the analysis phase, as the reasoner checks possible logical inferences and avoids common fallacies.
Generating and Proposing Concrete Solution Candidates

This function involves the generation and proposal of specific, actionable ideas or methods that could address a problem or fulfill a task. Sentences in this category typically introduce possible materials, tools, techniques, or approaches (e.g., "Maybe using clay if it's available," "Or use fabric scraps to make collages"), often using tentative language ("maybe," "perhaps," "I could use"). INCLUDED are explicit suggestions for how something might be done, constructed, or solved, whether as a primary solution or an alternative; NOT INCLUDED are evaluations, justifications, abstract theorizing, or final decisions. These sentences usually appear in the exploratory or ideation phase of reasoning, often following problem analysis and preceding evaluation or selection of the best approach.
Final Answer Assertion

These sentences explicitly state the model's final answer or conclusion after completing its reasoning process. They typically synthesize prior analysis, sometimes expressing confidence or summarizing the rationale, and present the answer in a direct, declarative form (e.g., "So, the answer is X," "Therefore, the answer should be Y," "I think that's the correct answer"). This category includes only statements that serve to deliver the final output or decision, not intermediate steps, justifications, or ongoing reasoning. They almost always appear at or near the end of the reasoning trace, marking the transition from reasoning to answer delivery.

0.title: Pattern Identification and Explicit Enumeration
0.description: These sentences serve the function of explicitly listing, enumerating, or breaking down the elements of a sequence, set, or pattern in order to identify regularities or rules governing the data. Included are statements that systematically lay out the given items (numbers, letters, shapes, etc.), calculate differences or ratios, or otherwise make the structure of the data explicit for subsequent analysis. Not included are sentences that merely state the final pattern, draw conclusions, or perform calculations without first enumerating or analyzing the raw elements. These sentences typically appear early in the reasoning process, immediately after the problem is introduced and before any conclusions or predictions are made.

1.title: Expanding the Scope of Consideration
1.description: These sentences serve the cognitive function of deliberately broadening the reasoning process by introducing additional relevant factors, perspectives, or dimensions that have not yet been addressed. This includes bringing in new variables, implications, examples, or domains (e.g., economic, ethical, historical) for further analysis, often signaled by phrases like "I should also think about..." or "I'm also considering...". This category does NOT include initial identification of the main problem, deep analysis of a single factor, or summarizing conclusions; rather, these sentences typically appear after some initial reasoning, as the thinker seeks to ensure a comprehensive and multi-faceted exploration of the issue.

2.title: Problem Framing and Task Articulation
2.description: These sentences serve to explicitly state the central question, problem, or causal scenario that the reasoning process will address. They include the identification of a phenomenon, system, or hypothetical change and articulate the need to "figure out," "understand," or "analyze" its mechanisms, effects, or consequences. This function does NOT include the exploration of possible solutions, hypothesis generation, evidence evaluation, or step-by-step reasoning; rather, it is limited to the initial articulation of the reasoning target. These sentences almost always appear at or near the very beginning of a reasoning trace, setting the stage for subsequent analysis.

3.title: Enumeration of Total Possibilities Using Combinatorial Formulas
3.description: This function involves explicitly calculating or stating the total number of possible outcomes in a scenario by applying combinatorial formulas (such as combinations, permutations, or exponentiation for independent choices). Included are sentences that identify, set up, or compute the total count of arrangements, selections, or outcomes—often referencing formulas like C(n, k), P(n, k), n!, or expressions like 6^5. Not included are sentences that count favorable outcomes, describe problem constraints, or interpret the meaning of the result. These sentences typically appear early in probability or counting problems, immediately after the problem setup and before calculating probabilities or favorable cases.

4.description: These sentences serve to propose possible explanations or mechanisms underlying observed phenomena or facts, often using tentative language ("maybe," "I think," "it has to do with," "perhaps," "or maybe"). This function includes the generation of causal or structural hypotheses about how or why something works, typically drawing on prior knowledge or analogies, but does NOT include definitive statements, direct recall of facts, or the evaluation/selection of hypotheses. These sentences usually appear in the exploratory or sense-making phase of reasoning, often after the problem is introduced but before a final answer or conclusion is reached.

5.title: Retrieval and Articulation of Background Knowledge
5.description: These sentences serve to recall, state, or paraphrase relevant factual information, definitions, or general properties from memory or prior knowledge, often as a foundation for further reasoning. Included are statements that explicitly present known facts, concepts, or examples (e.g., "I remember that artists use palettes to mix colors," "A cube has six faces, all squares, and all edges are equal in length"). Not included are sentences that interpret, analyze, hypothesize, or draw conclusions from this knowledge, nor those that merely express uncertainty or metacognitive reflection. These sentences typically appear early or mid-way in reasoning, immediately before or during the process of applying knowledge to the problem at hand.

6.title: Initiation of Deliberate, Stepwise Analytical Reasoning
6.description: These sentences explicitly signal the transition into a focused, methodical, and often step-by-step reasoning process. They serve to orient the model (and reader) toward breaking down a problem into manageable parts, often after an initial statement of the problem or when encountering complexity or uncertainty. INCLUDED are metacognitive prompts that announce the intent to analyze, decompose, or reconsider the problem systematically (e.g., "Let me think about this step by step," "Let me try to figure this out step by step," "Let me try to break this down"). NOT INCLUDED are actual analytical steps, conclusions, or mere restatements of the problem; these sentences do not perform reasoning themselves but rather initiate or re-initiate the analytical process. They typically appear at the beginning of the reasoning sequence or at key junctures where a new line of analysis is about to begin.

7.title: Generating Conditional Predictions and Inferences Based on Hypothetical Manipulations
7.description: These sentences perform the cognitive function of predicting or inferring the outcome of a hypothetical action or manipulation (e.g., "if I slice...", "if I rotate...", "if the light is coming from...") applied to a mathematical or physical object. Included are statements that explicitly describe what would result from a specific operation or condition, often using conditional or subjunctive language ("if...then...", "should be...", "would be..."). Not included are general definitions, explanations of concepts, or statements summarizing conclusions without reference to a hypothetical manipulation. These sentences typically appear in the middle of reasoning traces, as the thinker explores possible outcomes to test or build toward a solution.

8.title: Generating Alternative Hypothesis Candidates
8.description: These sentences serve the function of proposing possible explanations, interpretations, or candidate answers in response to a problem or question, often in a speculative or brainstorming mode. Included are statements that introduce new, distinct possibilities (e.g., "Maybe it's a metaphor," "Alternatively, maybe it's a keyhole," "Wait, maybe it's about the function"), typically using hedging language ("maybe," "perhaps," "alternatively," "another thought"). NOT INCLUDED are sentences that evaluate, justify, or select among these candidates, nor those that elaborate on a single hypothesis in depth. These sentences usually appear in the exploratory, generative phase of reasoning, often clustered after initial problem comprehension and before narrowing down or evaluating options.

9.title: Initial Problem Framing and Knowledge Activation
9.description: These sentences serve to initiate the reasoning process by explicitly framing the problem, recalling relevant prior knowledge, or identifying foundational concepts needed for further reasoning. INCLUDED are statements that mark the start of reasoning, such as recalling definitions, visualizing objects, or clarifying what needs to be understood before proceeding. NOT INCLUDED are sentences that analyze, synthesize, or evaluate information after the initial setup, or those that draw conclusions. 10.title: Stepwise Explicit Calculation Execution
10.description: This function involves the explicit, step-by-step computation of arithmetic or algebraic operations, often breaking down complex calculations into smaller, manageable parts and showing intermediate results. Included are sentences that perform and narrate each sub-step of a calculation (e.g., multiplying, adding, dividing, simplifying fractions), often using phrases like "let me compute," "so," or "then," and presenting partial results. NOT INCLUDED are sentences that merely state the final answer, set up the problem, explain the reasoning behind the calculation, or interpret the result; only the explicit execution of calculation steps belongs here. 11.title: Projecting Consequences and Secondary Effects

NOT INCLUDED are direct explanations of mechanisms, definitions, or statements of fact; these sentences do not describe how something works, but rather what might happen as a result. 12.title: Expression of Uncertainty or Doubt About a Prior Hypothesis or Step
12.description: These sentences explicitly signal the reasoner's uncertainty, doubt, or lack of confidence regarding the correctness, relevance, or sufficiency of a preceding idea, hypothesis, or reasoning step. NOT INCLUDED are general expressions of confusion ("I don't understand"), requests for information, or uncertainty about facts not directly tied to a just-stated reasoning step. These sentences typically appear immediately after the reasoner proposes or considers a possible answer, explanation, or line of reasoning, serving as a metacognitive check before proceeding.

14.title: Testing the Converse or Inverse of a Conditional Statement
14.description: This function involves explicitly examining whether the converse (or sometimes the inverse) of a given conditional statement holds true. Sentences in this category restate the original conditional (e.g., "If A, then B") and then question or analyze whether the reverse ("If B, then A") or the negation ("If not B, then not A") is valid, often using examples or logical notation. Included are statements that clarify the directionality of implication, test sufficiency vs. necessity, or highlight that the original conditional does not guarantee its converse; NOT included are sentences that merely restate the original conditional, provide definitions, or draw direct conclusions without testing the reverse relationship. 15.title: Generating and Proposing Concrete Solution Candidates
15.description: This function involves the generation and proposal of specific, actionable ideas or methods that could address a problem or fulfill a task. Sentences in this category typically introduce possible materials, tools, techniques, or approaches (e.g., "Maybe using clay if it's available," "Or use fabric scraps to make collages"), often using tentative language ("maybe," "perhaps," "I could use"). INCLUDED are explicit suggestions for how something might be done, constructed, or solved, whether as a primary solution or an alternative; NOT INCLUDED are evaluations, justifications, abstract theorizing, or final decisions. These sentences usually appear in the exploratory or ideation phase of reasoning, often following problem analysis and preceding evaluation or selection of the best approach.

16.title: Final Answer Assertion
16.description: These sentences explicitly state the model's final answer or conclusion after completing its reasoning process. They typically synthesize prior analysis, sometimes expressing confidence or summarizing the rationale, and present the answer in a direct, declarative form (e.g., "So, the answer is X," "Therefore, the answer should be Y," "I think that's the correct answer"). This category includes only statements that serve to deliver the final output or decision, not intermediate steps, justifications, or ongoing reasoning. They almost always appear at or near the end of the reasoning trace, marking the transition from reasoning to answer delivery.
examples: So, I think I'm confident that the probability is 1/24

So, the answer should be "scene

So, the answer should be "bottom
So, the answer should be the digestive system

categories: Pattern Identification and Articulation in Sequential Reasoning

This function involves explicitly identifying, listing, and describing the underlying pattern or rule governing a sequence of items (numbers, letters, shapes, etc.) as part of solving a pattern or sequence problem. Sentences in this category typically enumerate elements, calculate differences or ratios, and then state the observed regularity (e.g., "The differences are increasing by 1 each time" or "Each number is a perfect square"). INCLUDED are statements that directly analyze, summarize, or articulate the pattern or structure in the data; NOT INCLUDED are steps that merely restate the problem, make predictions, or perform unrelated calculations. These sentences usually appear after initial data listing and before or during the process of generating the next item or making a prediction.
Stepwise Arithmetic Computation and Intermediate Result Tracking

These sentences explicitly narrate the process of performing arithmetic operations (such as addition, multiplication, division, or subtraction) on given numbers, often chaining multiple operations and reporting intermediate results. Included are statements that detail each computational step, including the operation performed, the operands, and the resulting value, sometimes with commentary on whether the result meets a target or constraint. Not included are sentences that merely state the final answer, discuss strategies without performing calculations, or reflect on the reasoning process without explicit arithmetic steps. These sentences typically appear in the middle phase of problem-solving, as the LLM works through possible combinations and calculations to approach a solution.
Analogy Structure Identification and Mapping

This function explicitly identifies and articulates the underlying structural pattern of analogy or proportional reasoning problems (e.g., "A is to B as C is to D"). It involves recognizing the analogy format, mapping the elements to their respective roles, and sometimes restating the analogy in abstract or variable terms (A, B, C, D) to clarify the relational structure. INCLUDED are sentences that (a) state the analogy structure, (b) assign specific items to analogy slots, or (c) describe the type of relationship (e.g., cause-effect, part-whole) being mapped; NOT INCLUDED are sentences that propose answers, explain the content of the analogy, or reason about the relationships themselves. These sentences typically appear early in the reasoning process, immediately after the problem is presented and before solution generation, serving to frame and formalize the analogy for subsequent analysis.
Retrieval and Stating of Background Knowledge or Definitions

These sentences explicitly recall, state, or paraphrase relevant factual knowledge, definitions, or properties needed for the current problem. Included are statements that introduce or clarify basic facts, standard definitions, or well-known properties (e.g., "A cube has six faces, all squares," "First, I know that a standard deck has 52 cards..."). NOT INCLUDED are sentences that apply, analyze, or manipulate this knowledge, nor those that make inferences or perform calculations. These sentences typically appear early in the reasoning process, often as foundational steps before problem-specific analysis or computation.
Enumerating and Defining Outcome Spaces

This function involves explicitly identifying, quantifying, or defining the total set of possible outcomes (the "sample space") and/or the subset of favorable outcomes relevant to a combinatorial or probabilistic problem. Sentences in this category typically use phrases like "the total number of ways," "the number of possible outcomes," or "the number of favorable outcomes," and often reference combinatorial formulas (e.g., combinations, permutations). INCLUDED are statements that set up the denominator (total outcomes) and/or numerator (favorable outcomes) for probability calculations or combinatorial reasoning. NOT INCLUDED are sentences that perform the actual calculation, interpret results, or discuss problem context without specifying outcome spaces. These sentences usually appear early or mid-way in the reasoning process, immediately before or during the setup of a formal calculation.
Generating and Evaluating Alternative Hypotheses

This function involves proposing possible answers, explanations, or interpretations that might fit the problem at hand, often using phrases like "maybe," "alternatively," "wait," or "another thought." These sentences explicitly consider multiple candidate solutions or conceptual framings, sometimes immediately critiquing or discarding them, but always as part of a divergent thinking process. This operation is typically found in the exploratory or middle phase of reasoning, after initial understanding but before final selection or justification; it does NOT include the final answer, nor does it summarize or justify a chosen solution.
Projecting Downstream Consequences and Secondary Effects

These sentences serve the cognitive function of anticipating and articulating possible downstream consequences, secondary effects, or ripple effects that may result from a proposed change, event, or policy. Included in this category are statements that speculate about indirect impacts—economic, social, environmental, or cultural—that extend beyond the immediate or primary outcome, often using modal verbs ("could," "might," "may") and phrases like "this could lead to," "might also," or "on the flip side." Not included are direct explanations of primary effects, restatements of the initial scenario, or evaluations of desirability; these sentences typically appear after the main outcome has been established, expanding the reasoning to consider broader or less obvious ramifications.
Generating Alternative Solution Proposals

These sentences serve the function of proposing possible methods, strategies, or solutions to a problem, typically introduced with hedging or speculative language (e.g., "Maybe I can...", "Or perhaps...", "Another idea is..."). INCLUDED are statements that suggest concrete, actionable alternatives or approaches that could plausibly address the problem at hand, regardless of whether they are ultimately chosen or evaluated as correct. NOT INCLUDED are sentences that merely analyze, critique, or select among options, or that summarize, justify, or reflect on previous proposals. These sentences most often appear in the middle phase of reasoning, after the problem is understood but before a final solution is selected or justified.
Conditional Visualization and Mental Simulation of Geometric Transformations

These sentences perform the cognitive function of mentally simulating or visualizing the outcome of a geometric operation (such as slicing, rotating, folding, or projecting) under specific conditions, often introduced by "if" or "when" clauses. Included are statements that hypothesize or predict the resulting shape, cross-section, or shadow given a particular manipulation or orientation of a geometric object. Not included are general definitions, factual recalls, or procedural steps that do not involve conditional or hypothetical visualization; these sentences typically appear during the exploration or solution-construction phase, as the reasoner works through possible scenarios to build intuition or test hypotheses.
Stepwise Arithmetic Computation Execution

This function involves explicitly carrying out multi-step arithmetic calculations, often breaking down complex operations (like multiplication, division, or exponentiation) into smaller, sequential steps and sometimes showing intermediate results. Included are sentences that narrate the process of performing arithmetic (e.g., "12 × 11 = 132", "Now, divide that by 6: 62,496 / 6 = 10,416"), including partial sums, products, or quotients, and the chaining of these results. NOT included are sentences that merely state a formula, set up an equation, or interpret the meaning of a result—this category is strictly for the execution of the arithmetic itself. These sentences typically appear in the middle of reasoning traces, immediately after a formula or plan is established and before the final answer or interpretation is given.
Expanding the Scope of Consideration

These sentences serve the cognitive function of deliberately broadening the reasoning process by introducing additional relevant factors, perspectives, or dimensions that have not yet been addressed. This includes bringing in new variables, implications, or contexts (e.g., economic, social, environmental, historical) to ensure a more comprehensive analysis. It does NOT include sentences that merely elaborate on already-discussed points, summarize, or draw conclusions; rather, these sentences typically appear after an initial line of reasoning and signal a shift to consider further aspects before final synthesis or judgment.
Final Answer Assertion

These sentences serve the cognitive function of explicitly stating the LLM's final answer or conclusion after completing its reasoning process. They typically synthesize prior analysis, often using summary phrases like "So," "Therefore," "I think," or "putting it all together," and directly present the answer, solution, or probability. This category includes only those utterances that unambiguously declare the final output or decision, not intermediate steps, partial hypotheses, or ongoing deliberations; they almost always appear at or near the end of a reasoning trace, marking the transition from reasoning to answer delivery.
Analogical Relationship Articulation

These sentences explicitly state or clarify the underlying relationship between two pairs of items in analogy problems, often by identifying the shared function, part-whole structure, or role correspondence (e.g., "Wheels are a part of a vehicle, and legs are a part of an organism"). Included are sentences that map or explain the analogy by making the relational structure explicit, sometimes using phrases like "just like," "because," "so," or "in the same way." NOT INCLUDED are sentences that merely select an answer, restate the analogy without explanation, or provide unrelated background information. These sentences typically appear after initial consideration of the analogy and just before or as part of the answer justification.
Expression of Uncertainty or Doubt About a Candidate Hypothesis

These sentences explicitly express the model's uncertainty, doubt, or lack of confidence regarding the correctness, applicability, or sufficiency of a just-proposed idea, hypothesis, or partial answer. Included are statements that directly qualify or hedge a preceding suggestion (e.g., "But I'm not sure if that's the case," "But I'm not entirely sure," "I'm not sure if that's the right fit"), often immediately following a speculative or tentative reasoning step. Not included are general expressions of confusion, requests for information, or uncertainty about the problem as a whole before any hypothesis is proposed. These sentences typically appear after the model has generated a possible answer or line of reasoning, serving as a metacognitive check or self-monitoring step before proceeding further.
Generating Mechanistic Explanations and Hypotheses

These sentences serve to propose plausible underlying mechanisms, causal processes, or structural explanations for observed phenomena or questions. They often use language like "maybe," "I think," "it has to do with," or "because," and focus on how or why something works at a physical, chemical, or conceptual level (e.g., particle movement, molecular structure, energy transfer). INCLUDED are sentences that articulate possible causal chains or mechanistic models, even if tentative or speculative; NOT INCLUDED are sentences that merely state facts, summarize, evaluate, or make decisions without proposing a mechanism. These sentences typically appear in the exploratory or elaborative middle phase of reasoning, after the problem is introduced but before conclusions or summaries are drawn.
Denial of Converse or Affirming the Consequent Fallacy

These sentences explicitly caution against inferring the converse of a conditional statement (i.e., "If P then Q" does not imply "If Q then P") or warn against the fallacy of affirming the consequent. They highlight that the presence of an effect (Q) does not guarantee the presence of a specific cause (P), often by providing alternative explanations or emphasizing insufficiency of evidence. This function is typically found after an initial inference, serving to correct, qualify, or prevent an invalid conclusion by clarifying the logical relationship between conditions and outcomes; it does not include general skepticism, unrelated counterexamples, or mere restatements of the original conditional.
Problem Formulation and Task Framing

These sentences explicitly articulate the central question, problem, or scenario the reasoning process will address, often by restating or paraphrasing the task in the LLM's own words. This function includes identifying what needs to be figured out, specifying the phenomenon or system under consideration, and sometimes hinting at the approach (e.g., "I'm trying to figure out..."). It does NOT include background explanation, hypothesis generation, or step-by-step solution attempts. These sentences almost always appear at or near the very beginning of a reasoning trace, serving to orient and focus the subsequent reasoning.
Initiation of Deliberate Analytical Thinking

These sentences explicitly signal the LLM's transition into a focused, step-by-step analytical or problem-solving mode. They serve to pause, reorient, or structure the reasoning process, often marking the start of a new line of thought, a reconsideration, or a systematic breakdown of the problem. INCLUDED are metacognitive prompts such as "Let me think about this step by step," "Let me try to break this down," or "Let me think of another angle," which announce the intent to analyze, reconsider, or approach the problem methodically. NOT INCLUDED are statements that actually perform reasoning, state facts, or draw conclusions—these sentences do not advance the solution directly but instead prepare or organize the cognitive approach. They typically appear at the beginning of reasoning segments, at points of uncertainty, or when shifting strategies.

9.title: Stepwise Arithmetic Computation Execution
9.description: This function involves explicitly carrying out multi-step arithmetic calculations, often breaking down complex operations (like multiplication, division, or exponentiation) into smaller, sequential steps and sometimes showing intermediate results. Included are sentences that narrate the process of performing arithmetic (e.g., "12 × 11 = 132", "Now, divide that by 6: 62,496 / 6 = 10,416"), including partial sums, products, or quotients, and the chaining of these results. NOT included are sentences that merely state a formula, set up an equation, or interpret the meaning of a result—this category is strictly for the execution of the arithmetic itself. These sentences typically appear in the middle of reasoning traces, immediately after a formula or plan is established and before the final answer or interpretation is given.

10.title: Expanding the Scope of Consideration
10.description: These sentences serve the cognitive function of deliberately broadening the reasoning process by introducing additional relevant factors, perspectives, or dimensions that have not yet been addressed. This includes bringing in new variables, implications, or contexts (e.g., economic, social, environmental, historical) to ensure a more comprehensive analysis. It does NOT include sentences that merely elaborate on already-discussed points, summarize, or draw conclusions; rather, these sentences typically appear after an initial line of reasoning and signal a shift to consider further aspects before final synthesis or judgment.

11.title: Final Answer Assertion
11.description: These sentences serve the cognitive function of explicitly stating the LLM's final answer or conclusion after completing its reasoning process. They typically synthesize prior analysis, often using summary phrases like "So," "Therefore," "I think," or "putting it all together," and directly present the answer, solution, or probability. This category includes only those utterances that unambiguously declare the final output or decision, not intermediate steps, partial hypotheses, or ongoing deliberations; they almost always appear at or near the end of a reasoning trace, marking the transition from reasoning to answer delivery.
examples: So, I think I'm confident that the probability is 1/24

12.title: Analogical Relationship Articulation
12.description: These sentences explicitly state or clarify the underlying relationship between two pairs of items in analogy problems, often by identifying the shared function, part-whole structure, or role correspondence (e.g., "Wheels are a part of a vehicle, and legs are a part of an organism"). Included are sentences that map or explain the analogy by making the relational structure explicit, sometimes using phrases like "just like," "because," "so," or "in the same way." NOT INCLUDED are sentences that merely select an answer, restate the analogy without explanation, or provide unrelated background information. These sentences typically appear after initial consideration of the analogy and just before or as part of the answer justification.

13.title: Expression of Uncertainty or Doubt About a Candidate Hypothesis
13.description: These sentences explicitly express the model's uncertainty, doubt, or lack of confidence regarding the correctness, applicability, or sufficiency of a just-proposed idea, hypothesis, or partial answer. Included are statements that directly qualify or hedge a preceding suggestion (e.g., "But I'm not sure if that's the case," "But I'm not entirely sure," "I'm not sure if that's the right fit"), often immediately following a speculative or tentative reasoning step. Not included are general expressions of confusion, requests for information, or uncertainty about the problem as a whole before any hypothesis is proposed. These sentences typically appear after the model has generated a possible answer or line of reasoning, serving as a metacognitive check or self-monitoring step before proceeding further.

14.title: Generating Mechanistic Explanations and Hypotheses
14.description: These sentences serve to propose plausible underlying mechanisms, causal processes, or structural explanations for observed phenomena or questions. They often use language like "maybe," "I think," "it has to do with," or "because," and focus on how or why something works at a physical, chemical, or conceptual level (e.g., particle movement, molecular structure, energy transfer). INCLUDED are sentences that articulate possible causal chains or mechanistic models, even if tentative or speculative; NOT INCLUDED are sentences that merely state facts, summarize, evaluate, or make decisions without proposing a mechanism. These sentences typically appear in the exploratory or elaborative middle phase of reasoning, after the problem is introduced but before conclusions or summaries are drawn.

15.title: Denial of Converse or Affirming the Consequent Fallacy
15.description: These sentences explicitly caution against inferring the converse of a conditional statement (i.e., "If P then Q" does not imply "If Q then P") or warn against the fallacy of affirming the consequent. They highlight that the presence of an effect (Q) does not guarantee the presence of a specific cause (P), often by providing alternative explanations or emphasizing insufficiency of evidence. This function is typically found after an initial inference, serving to correct, qualify, or prevent an invalid conclusion by clarifying the logical relationship between conditions and outcomes; it does not include general skepticism, unrelated counterexamples, or mere restatements of the original conditional.
examples: So, just because Jane passed the exam (P), we can't conclude she studied hard (S), because maybe there are other reasons why she passed

16.title: Problem Formulation and Task Framing
16.description: These sentences explicitly articulate the central question, problem, or scenario the reasoning process will address, often by restating or paraphrasing the task in the LLM's own words. This function includes identifying what needs to be figured out, specifying the phenomenon or system under consideration, and sometimes hinting at the approach (e.g., "I'm trying to figure out..."). It does NOT include background explanation, hypothesis generation, or step-by-step solution attempts. These sentences almost always appear at or near the very beginning of a reasoning trace, serving to orient and focus the subsequent reasoning.
examples: Okay, so I'm trying to figure out how gravity affects objects of different masses

17.title: Initiation of Deliberate Analytical Thinking
17.description: These sentences explicitly signal the LLM's transition into a focused, step-by-step analytical or problem-solving mode. They serve to pause, reorient, or structure the reasoning process, often marking the start of a new line of thought, a reconsideration, or a systematic breakdown of the problem. INCLUDED are metacognitive prompts such as "Let me think about this step by step," "Let me try to break this down," or "Let me think of another angle," which announce the intent to analyze, reconsider, or approach the problem methodically. NOT INCLUDED are statements that actually perform reasoning, state facts, or draw conclusions—these sentences do not advance the solution directly but instead prepare or organize the cognitive approach. They typically appear at the beginning of reasoning segments, at points of uncertainty, or when shifting strategies.
examples: Let me try to visualize it
Let me think again
Let me try to break this down
Hmm, let me think about this step by step
Let me think about it step by step
Let me think about this step by step
Let me think
Let me think
Let me think
Let me think about this step by step
Let me think about this step by step
Let me think about this step by step
Let me think about this step by step
Let me think about this step by step
Let me think about this step by step

categories: Problem Framing and Task Identification

These sentences explicitly articulate the central question, problem, or phenomenon the reasoning process will address, often rephrasing or clarifying the task in the LLM's own words. This function includes statements that set the scope and focus of the reasoning, such as "I'm trying to figure out..." or "I need to understand...," but does NOT include background information, definitions, or any steps toward solution or analysis. These sentences almost always appear at or near the very beginning of a reasoning trace, serving as the entry point that orients the subsequent reasoning.
Synthesis and Uncertainty Framing Statements

These sentences serve to synthesize the preceding analysis by summarizing the complexity, trade-offs, and multifaceted nature of the issue, often explicitly acknowledging uncertainty, limitations, or the need for further consideration. Included are statements that (a) encapsulate the overall findings, (b) highlight the presence of both positive and negative outcomes, (c) stress the complexity or interconnectedness of the issue, and/or (d) express uncertainty or incomplete knowledge about certain aspects. Not included are sentences that introduce new evidence, propose specific solutions, or detail individual causal mechanisms. These statements typically appear toward the end of a reasoning trace, functioning as concluding or transitional remarks that wrap up the analysis or set the stage for final conclusions.
Final Explicit Answer Articulation

This function involves explicitly stating the final answer or conclusion reached after the reasoning process, often prefaced by summary phrases such as "So," "Therefore," or "putting it all together." Included in this category are sentences that directly present the solution, selected option, or filled-in blank, sometimes with a brief justification or expression of confidence. Not included are intermediate steps, partial conclusions, or summary statements that do not directly articulate the final answer; these sentences almost always appear at or near the end of the reasoning trace, serving as the culmination of the reasoning process.
Generating Mechanistic Explanations (Causal Hypothesizing)

These sentences propose plausible underlying mechanisms or causal processes to explain observed phenomena, often by referencing physical, chemical, or structural properties (e.g., molecular arrangement, electron mobility, density). This function involves hypothesizing "how" or "why" something happens at a mechanistic level, frequently using language like "maybe," "because," or "it has to do with." INCLUDED are sentences that attempt to fill explanatory gaps by positing specific causal chains or structures; NOT INCLUDED are mere restatements of facts, surface-level descriptions, or summaries of known relationships without hypothesizing about underlying mechanisms. These sentences typically appear in the middle of reasoning traces, after the problem is introduced and before a final conclusion is drawn.
Step-by-Step Arithmetic Computation

This function involves explicitly performing and narrating individual arithmetic operations (addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, exponentiation) as intermediate steps toward a larger calculation or solution. Included are sentences that break down complex calculations into smaller, sequential arithmetic steps, often showing partial results or sub-calculations. Not included are statements that merely state a final answer, set up an equation, or describe the reasoning strategy without actually carrying out the arithmetic. These sentences typically appear in the middle of the reasoning process, following problem setup and preceding the final answer or conclusion.
Generating Alternative Solution Proposals

These sentences serve the function of brainstorming or proposing multiple possible methods, approaches, or solutions to a problem, often using "maybe," "perhaps," "or," or "another idea" to introduce each option. INCLUDED are statements that suggest concrete, actionable alternatives or creative ideas for achieving a goal, typically without yet evaluating or selecting among them. NOT INCLUDED are sentences that analyze, justify, or compare options, or that summarize or conclude; these sentences usually appear in the middle phase of reasoning, after the problem is understood but before a final decision or synthesis is made.
Conditional Visualization and Hypothetical Manipulation of Geometric Objects

These sentences perform the cognitive function of mentally simulating the outcome of specific geometric operations—such as slicing, projecting, folding, or rotating—on shapes, typically using conditional ("if...then...") or hypothetical constructions. Included are statements that predict or describe the result of a geometric transformation or manipulation under a specified condition (e.g., "If I slice the cone parallel to the axis, the intersection should be a curve"). Not included are general definitions, factual recalls, or explanations of why the outcome occurs; these sentences focus on what would be observed or produced by the operation. They tend to appear in the middle of reasoning traces, as the thinker explores possible scenarios to build intuition or test hypotheses about the problem.
Enumeration of Total Possibility Space

These sentences explicitly calculate or state the total number of possible outcomes, arrangements, or combinations relevant to a problem scenario—typically as the denominator in a probability or combinatorial reasoning process. Included are statements that define the full set of possible cases (e.g., "the total number of possible hands is C(52, 5)"), whether by formula, calculation, or verbal description. Not included are sentences that enumerate only favorable/successful outcomes, describe constraints, or discuss probability formulas without specifying the total possibility count. These sentences almost always appear early or mid-way in the reasoning process, immediately before or after identifying favorable outcomes, and are foundational for subsequent probability or ratio calculations.
Analogical Mapping and Solution Articulation

These sentences perform the cognitive function of explicitly mapping the structural relationships between elements in analogy problems and articulating the inferred solution. They synthesize the analogy’s structure (A is to B as C is to D), identify the missing element by drawing a parallel between the known pairs, and often present the answer in a "So, if X is to Y, then Z is to ___" or "So, the answer is ___" format. INCLUDED are sentences that directly state the analogy mapping and propose the solution or missing term; NOT INCLUDED are sentences that merely describe the analogy, list possible options, or analyze the analogy’s components without committing to a mapping or answer. These sentences typically appear at the culmination of the analogy reasoning process, immediately before or as the answer is given.
Metacognitive Initiation of Deliberate Reasoning

These sentences explicitly signal the LLM's conscious decision to engage in active, stepwise, or alternative reasoning, often marking a transition from initial understanding or recall to systematic problem-solving. Included are phrases that indicate the model is about to break down the problem, consider a new approach, or re-examine the issue (e.g., "Let me think about this step by step," "Let me try to figure this out," "Let me think of another angle"). Not included are actual reasoning steps, conclusions, or factual recall—these sentences serve purely as metacognitive markers or self-instructions. They typically appear at the beginning of the reasoning process, at points of uncertainty, or when shifting strategies.
Retrieval and Articulation of Background Knowledge or Definitions

These sentences serve to recall and explicitly state relevant factual knowledge, definitions, or prototypical features about concepts, objects, or relationships that are pertinent to the problem at hand. Included are statements that define, describe, or clarify what something is, what it does, or how it is typically categorized (e.g., "A wing is part of an airplane or a bird, right", "First, I know that a lighthouse is a tall structure built near the sea to help ships navigate"). Not included are sentences that apply this knowledge to the specific problem, make inferences, evaluate options, or synthesize information. These sentences typically appear early in the reasoning process, often immediately after the problem is introduced, to establish a factual foundation for subsequent analysis.
Generating and Proposing Alternative Hypotheses

This function involves the explicit generation and verbalization of possible answers, explanations, or conceptual frameworks in response to a problem or question. Sentences in this category typically introduce a new candidate solution or interpretive angle, often using hedging language ("maybe," "perhaps," "alternatively," "wait, maybe," "another thought/angle," "or perhaps"). INCLUDED are statements that propose a specific hypothesis, answer, or conceptual approach for consideration, regardless of whether the suggestion is immediately accepted or rejected. NOT INCLUDED are sentences that evaluate, justify, or eliminate previously proposed hypotheses, nor those that summarize, conclude, or explain reasoning steps. These sentences tend to appear in the exploratory or brainstorming phase of reasoning, often clustered before or between evaluation and selection of final answers.
Expression of Uncertainty or Doubt About a Candidate Hypothesis

These sentences explicitly express the model's uncertainty, doubt, or lack of confidence regarding a specific hypothesis, explanation, or step just proposed or considered. Included are statements that directly question the validity, fit, correctness, or applicability of a preceding idea (e.g., "But I'm not sure if that's the intended answer," "Hmm, that doesn't quite make sense," "But I'm not sure how that would work"). NOT INCLUDED are general expressions of confusion without reference to a specific hypothesis, or initial expressions of ignorance before any candidate idea is proposed. These sentences typically appear immediately after the model has generated or evaluated a possible answer, serving as a metacognitive check before proceeding or revising the reasoning.
Concrete Scenario Instantiation and Paraphrased Example Generation

This function involves the LLM generating specific, concrete scenarios, paraphrased restatements, or illustrative examples that instantiate an abstract rule, relationship, or riddle in tangible terms. These sentences often rephrase the problem using "like," "if," or "so" constructions, or by describing hypothetical or analogous situations that clarify the logic or constraints at play. INCLUDED are sentences that restate the core relationship or rule using new, concrete examples or paraphrased versions; NOT INCLUDED are abstract rule statements, direct answers, or meta-reasoning about the problem. These sentences typically appear in the middle of reasoning, after the rule or relationship is identified but before or during the process of testing, validating, or explaining it.
**Testing or Refuting Converse/Inverse Logical Inferences**

These sentences explicitly evaluate whether the converse or inverse of a given conditional or causal relationship holds—typically questioning or negating the inference from effect to cause (e.g., "just because B, does that mean A?"). This function includes statements that challenge the sufficiency or necessity of a condition, often using counterexamples or logical structure to show that the presence of an effect does not guarantee the presence of a specific cause. It does NOT include sentences that merely restate the original conditional, provide definitions, or summarize conclusions; rather, it focuses on interrogating or refuting the reverse implication. These sentences usually appear after the initial problem setup and during the core reasoning phase, often as the thinker tests the validity of possible inferences before reaching a final answer.
Anticipating and Weighing Downstream Consequences

These sentences serve to project and evaluate the broader, often indirect, effects that a proposed change, event, or action might have on related systems, sectors, or societal domains. Included are statements that hypothesize ripple effects, secondary impacts, or knock-on consequences—both positive and negative—beyond the immediate scope of the original scenario. Not included are direct explanations, definitions, or statements limited to immediate or primary effects. These sentences typically appear after an initial proposal or scenario is introduced, forming the core of the "what might happen next" or "broader implications" phase of reasoning.
Expanding the Scope of Consideration

These sentences serve the cognitive function of broadening the reasoning process by explicitly introducing additional factors, perspectives, or dimensions that may be relevant to the problem at hand. They typically signal a deliberate shift to include new variables, implications, or viewpoints that have not yet been addressed, often using phrases like "I also think about...", "I'm also considering...", or "Another thought is about...". This category includes statements that add new lines of inquiry or aspects for evaluation, but does NOT include sentences that merely elaborate on or analyze already-introduced points, nor those that summarize, conclude, or synthesize information. These sentences most often appear after an initial line of reasoning, as the thinker seeks to ensure a comprehensive and multifaceted analysis.
Pattern Identification and Explicit Enumeration

These sentences serve the function of explicitly identifying, listing, and analyzing the elements or structure of a sequence, set, or pattern as a preliminary step in reasoning. They include statements that enumerate terms, extract features (such as letters, numbers, or shapes), and articulate the observed order or relationship among elements, often using phrases like "First, I'll list...", "Next, I'll look at...", or "To determine the next... I'll analyze...". This category does NOT include sentences that propose solutions, make inferences, or state final answers; it is limited to the explicit, stepwise breakdown and observation of the given data or pattern, typically appearing early in the reasoning process to set up subsequent analysis.

3.title: Generating Mechanistic Explanations (Causal Hypothesizing)
3.description: These sentences propose plausible underlying mechanisms or causal processes to explain observed phenomena, often by referencing physical, chemical, or structural properties (e.g., molecular arrangement, electron mobility, density). This function involves hypothesizing "how" or "why" something happens at a mechanistic level, frequently using language like "maybe," "because," or "it has to do with." INCLUDED are sentences that attempt to fill explanatory gaps by positing specific causal chains or structures; NOT INCLUDED are mere restatements of facts, surface-level descriptions, or summaries of known relationships without hypothesizing about underlying mechanisms. These sentences typically appear in the middle of reasoning traces, after the problem is introduced and before a final conclusion is drawn.
examples: Maybe the molecules in honey are arranged in a way that makes it harder for them to move past each other, increasing the viscosity
Maybe temperature affects the solubility by influencing the kinetic energy of the molecules, making them move around more and interact better with water
Gases expand when heated because their molecules have more energy and push against the walls of the balloon more, making it bigger

4.title: Step-by-Step Arithmetic Computation
4.description: This function involves explicitly performing and narrating individual arithmetic operations (addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, exponentiation) as intermediate steps toward a larger calculation or solution. Included are sentences that break down complex calculations into smaller, sequential arithmetic steps, often showing partial results or sub-calculations. Not included are statements that merely state a final answer, set up an equation, or describe the reasoning strategy without actually carrying out the arithmetic. These sentences typically appear in the middle of the reasoning process, following problem setup and preceding the final answer or conclusion.

INCLUDED are statements that suggest concrete, actionable alternatives or creative ideas for achieving a goal, typically without yet evaluating or selecting among them. NOT INCLUDED are sentences that analyze, justify, or compare options, or that summarize or conclude; these sentences usually appear in the middle phase of reasoning, after the problem is understood but before a final decision or synthesis is made.

6.title: Conditional Visualization and Hypothetical Manipulation of Geometric Objects
6.description: These sentences perform the cognitive function of mentally simulating the outcome of specific geometric operations—such as slicing, projecting, folding, or rotating—on shapes, typically using conditional ("if...then...") or hypothetical constructions. Included are statements that predict or describe the result of a geometric transformation or manipulation under a specified condition (e.g., "If I slice the cone parallel to the axis, the intersection should be a curve"). Not included are general definitions, factual recalls, or explanations of why the outcome occurs; these sentences focus on what would be observed or produced by the operation. They tend to appear in the middle of reasoning traces, as the thinker explores possible scenarios to build intuition or test hypotheses about the problem.

7.title: Enumeration of Total Possibility Space
7.description: These sentences explicitly calculate or state the total number of possible outcomes, arrangements, or combinations relevant to a problem scenario—typically as the denominator in a probability or combinatorial reasoning process. Included are statements that define the full set of possible cases (e.g., "the total number of possible hands is C(52, 5)"), whether by formula, calculation, or verbal description. Not included are sentences that enumerate only favorable/successful outcomes, describe constraints, or discuss probability formulas without specifying the total possibility count. These sentences almost always appear early or mid-way in the reasoning process, immediately before or after identifying favorable outcomes, and are foundational for subsequent probability or ratio calculations.

8.title: Analogical Mapping and Solution Articulation
8.description: These sentences perform the cognitive function of explicitly mapping the structural relationships between elements in analogy problems and articulating the inferred solution. They synthesize the analogy’s structure (A is to B as C is to D), identify the missing element by drawing a parallel between the known pairs, and often present the answer in a "So, if X is to Y, then Z is to ___" or "So, the answer is ___" format. INCLUDED are sentences that directly state the analogy mapping and propose the solution or missing term; NOT INCLUDED are sentences that merely describe the analogy, list possible options, or analyze the analogy’s components without committing to a mapping or answer. These sentences typically appear at the culmination of the analogy reasoning process, immediately before or as the answer is given.

10.title: Metacognitive Initiation of Deliberate Reasoning
10.description: These sentences explicitly signal the LLM's conscious decision to engage in active, stepwise, or alternative reasoning, often marking a transition from initial understanding or recall to systematic problem-solving. Included are phrases that indicate the model is about to break down the problem, consider a new approach, or re-examine the issue (e.g., "Let me think about this step by step," "Let me try to figure this out," "Let me think of another angle"). Not included are actual reasoning steps, conclusions, or factual recall—these sentences serve purely as metacognitive markers or self-instructions. They typically appear at the beginning of the reasoning process, at points of uncertainty, or when shifting strategies.

11.title: Retrieval and Articulation of Background Knowledge or Definitions
11.description: These sentences serve to recall and explicitly state relevant factual knowledge, definitions, or prototypical features about concepts, objects, or relationships that are pertinent to the problem at hand. Included are statements that define, describe, or clarify what something is, what it does, or how it is typically categorized (e.g., "A wing is part of an airplane or a bird, right", "First, I know that a lighthouse is a tall structure built near the sea to help ships navigate"). Not included are sentences that apply this knowledge to the specific problem, make inferences, evaluate options, or synthesize information. These sentences typically appear early in the reasoning process, often immediately after the problem is introduced, to establish a factual foundation for subsequent analysis.

12.title: Generating and Proposing Alternative Hypotheses
12.description: This function involves the explicit generation and verbalization of possible answers, explanations, or conceptual frameworks in response to a problem or question. Sentences in this category typically introduce a new candidate solution or interpretive angle, often using hedging language ("maybe," "perhaps," "alternatively," "wait, maybe," "another thought/angle," "or perhaps"). INCLUDED are statements that propose a specific hypothesis, answer, or conceptual approach for consideration, regardless of whether the suggestion is immediately accepted or rejected. NOT INCLUDED are sentences that evaluate, justify, or eliminate previously proposed hypotheses, nor those that summarize, conclude, or explain reasoning steps. These sentences tend to appear in the exploratory or brainstorming phase of reasoning, often clustered before or between evaluation and selection of final answers.

13.title: Expression of Uncertainty or Doubt About a Candidate Hypothesis
13.description: These sentences explicitly express the model's uncertainty, doubt, or lack of confidence regarding a specific hypothesis, explanation, or step just proposed or considered. Included are statements that directly question the validity, fit, correctness, or applicability of a preceding idea (e.g., "But I'm not sure if that's the intended answer," "Hmm, that doesn't quite make sense," "But I'm not sure how that would work"). NOT INCLUDED are general expressions of confusion without reference to a specific hypothesis, or initial expressions of ignorance before any candidate idea is proposed. These sentences typically appear immediately after the model has generated or evaluated a possible answer, serving as a metacognitive check before proceeding or revising the reasoning.

14.title: Concrete Scenario Instantiation and Paraphrased Example Generation
14.description: This function involves the LLM generating specific, concrete scenarios, paraphrased restatements, or illustrative examples that instantiate an abstract rule, relationship, or riddle in tangible terms. These sentences often rephrase the problem using "like," "if," or "so" constructions, or by describing hypothetical or analogous situations that clarify the logic or constraints at play. INCLUDED are sentences that restate the core relationship or rule using new, concrete examples or paraphrased versions; NOT INCLUDED are abstract rule statements, direct answers, or meta-reasoning about the problem. 15.title: **Testing or Refuting Converse/Inverse Logical Inferences**
15.description: These sentences explicitly evaluate whether the converse or inverse of a given conditional or causal relationship holds—typically questioning or negating the inference from effect to cause (e.g., "just because B, does that mean A?"). This function includes statements that challenge the sufficiency or necessity of a condition, often using counterexamples or logical structure to show that the presence of an effect does not guarantee the presence of a specific cause. It does NOT include sentences that merely restate the original conditional, provide definitions, or summarize conclusions; rather, it focuses on interrogating or refuting the reverse implication. These sentences usually appear after the initial problem setup and during the core reasoning phase, often as the thinker tests the validity of possible inferences before reaching a final answer.

16.title: Anticipating and Weighing Downstream Consequences
16.description: These sentences serve to project and evaluate the broader, often indirect, effects that a proposed change, event, or action might have on related systems, sectors, or societal domains. Included are statements that hypothesize ripple effects, secondary impacts, or knock-on consequences—both positive and negative—beyond the immediate scope of the original scenario. Not included are direct explanations, definitions, or statements limited to immediate or primary effects. These sentences typically appear after an initial proposal or scenario is introduced, forming the core of the "what might happen next" or "broader implications" phase of reasoning.

17.title: Expanding the Scope of Consideration
17.description: These sentences serve the cognitive function of broadening the reasoning process by explicitly introducing additional factors, perspectives, or dimensions that may be relevant to the problem at hand. They typically signal a deliberate shift to include new variables, implications, or viewpoints that have not yet been addressed, often using phrases like "I also think about...", "I'm also considering...", or "Another thought is about...". This category includes statements that add new lines of inquiry or aspects for evaluation, but does NOT include sentences that merely elaborate on or analyze already-introduced points, nor those that summarize, conclude, or synthesize information. These sentences most often appear after an initial line of reasoning, as the thinker seeks to ensure a comprehensive and multifaceted analysis.

18.title: Pattern Identification and Explicit Enumeration
18.description: These sentences serve the function of explicitly identifying, listing, and analyzing the elements or structure of a sequence, set, or pattern as a preliminary step in reasoning. They include statements that enumerate terms, extract features (such as letters, numbers, or shapes), and articulate the observed order or relationship among elements, often using phrases like "First, I'll list...", "Next, I'll look at...", or "To determine the next... I'll analyze...". This category does NOT include sentences that propose solutions, make inferences, or state final answers; it is limited to the explicit, stepwise breakdown and observation of the given data or pattern, typically appearing early in the reasoning process to set up subsequent analysis.
